title: Does Reality Drive Straight Lines On Graphs, Or Do Straight Lines On Graphs Drive Reality?
summary:
Key ideas
- Graphs of historic trends can be used to argue that policies like the Clean Air Act didn't work.
- These arguments can be countered by considering control systems, which adjust to any unexpected advances/changes to achieve the desired outcomes.
- Control systems exist in various aspects of life, including environmental outcomes and technological progress.
- It is challenging to tell whether changes in trends are due to policies or control systems.

Key learnings
- Graphs of trends over time can be misleading and should be considered with caution, especially when used to argue against the effectiveness of policies.
- Control systems, which adjust to changes, should be considered when evaluating trends and the effectiveness of policies.
- Changes in trends can be due to policies, control systems or other factors that are difficult to discern, which makes it challenging to determine the effectiveness of policies.

Key questions
- Are control systems prevalent everywhere or only in specific aspects of life, such as environmental outcomes or technological progress?
- How can researchers distinguish whether changes in trends are due to policies, control systems or other factors?
- Is there research that compares the effectiveness of policies in different scenarios, considering the presence of control systems and other factors?
